page.title: 14Local history of Caerhun
page.content: The area is full of the remains of Pre-historic and Roman civilisations. At Bwlch-y-Ddeufaen are standing stones and the remains of round huts. East of Bwlch-y-Ddeufaen is a stone circle. To the east of Cae Coch, off the track to Rowen, is a well- preserved cromlech or burial chamber. On the other side of the track is another standing stone, Maen-y-Bardd, above Rowen. A strongly-walled Iron Age fort crowns the summit of Pen-y-Gaer; inside are the foundations of twelve round huts. To the south and west of the fort are two areas set with pointed stones to form a 'chevaux de frise' to deter any attackers. The many tracks were originally made by early man crossing from the coast at Aber to the River Conwy and further inland. The upland area was commonland until the Enclosures Act of 1832.
